body:
## Problem

**TL;DR**: soft wrap (`vim.g.man_hardwrap = 0`) breaks the formatting of wide tables.

My use case is to read man pages in Neovim with its great navigation.

It is common to resize the buffer displaying the man page. Either from Neovims great buffer resizing capabilities itself or from outside, e. g. terminal emulator or tiling window manager. While all code is properly wrapped on any resize, man pages often end up strangely formatted.


### Problem with Hard Wrap

When using hard wrap (`vim.g.man_hardwrap = 1`) the man page ends up badly formatted even by the smallest resizings.See following example, I opened neovim in a vertical split and opened a man page with `:hide Man systemd.unit`.

It was nicely formatted at first:
![hardwrap_pre-resize](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/121407246/ede2b942-7841-4b91-8073-40ec119e6f21)

But after a resize of 4 fields (`<C-w>4<`) many sentences broke for one word and created a bad formatting.
![hardwrap_post-resize-4](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/121407246/20132676-ab1a-426e-a4fb-cd00f8c77d08)


### Problem with Soft Wrap

The solution is to use soft wrap (`vim.g.man_hardwrap = 0`). Man pages with soft wrap work great, but the tables are poorly formatted.

View of `systemd.unit` in a narrow window:
![softwrap_splitcreen](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/121407246/c86fa618-d4cc-467c-8067-97e0141e0f83)

When having a wider window it is correctly formatted:
![softwrap_fullscren](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/121407246/c4e94325-efbe-41aa-b836-423b86837c47)

**I assume that Neovim want to write a table row always in one visible row, when using soft wrap (`vim.g.man_hardwrap = 0`), which leads to this strange formatting.**

## Steps to reproduce

1. open a window in your terminal emulator with under 180 columns.
2. Open a man page in neovim with soft wrap, e. g.: `nvim --clean "+lua vim.g.man_hardwrap = 0" "+hide Man systemd.unit"`. The behavior is the same then opening the man page inside of Neovim (`:hide Man systemd.unit`).
3. Scroll down to chapter _UNIT FILE LOAD PATH_ and look at _Table 2.  Load path when running in user mode (--user)._

## Expected behavior

**TL;DR**: I'd expect that Neovim in soft wrap mode also creates multi line cells.

When using hard wrap Neovim does format the table into multiple rows. So Neovim seem to have this capability somewhere and it should be possible that tables in soft wrap mode also get multi line cells.

Initial open with hard wrap in a narrow window:
![hardwrap_splitscreen](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/121407246/7dcc09bc-53fe-4d9d-9619-34f91a5fd370)

Initial open with hard wrap in a wide window:
![hardwrap_fullscren](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/121407246/6439f582-1486-41b9-9e23-a0e1ef46f2cb)


### Related Issues and Differentiation

This was previously discussed in other issues:

- https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/10748  
- https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/11436

Those issues where about setting the default behavior back to hard wrap. In contrast to these issues I'd expect Neovim to correctly format wide tables into multi line cells, also in soft wrap mode.


### Possible Solutions

As described in the _Problem_ section hard wrap is no good solution for a window, which regularly resized.

- In hard wrap mode the tables are much smaller than the available lines. Maybe it would be a solution to format the tables like in hard wrap mode also in soft wrap mode. This wouldn't erase the problem in its whole, but could minimize it.
- Also enable multi line cells when using soft wrap. I assume that this needs to regenerate the complete table at a resize event.


## Environment

### Neovim version (nvim -v)

`NVIM v0.10.0` and confirmed in `NVIM v0.11.0-dev-200+g9afa1fd35`

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

does not have this feature.

### Operating system/version

Arch Linux

### Terminal name/version

kitty 0.35.1

### $TERM environment variable

xterm-kitty

### Installation

system package manager (`pacman -S neovim`)

comment_data.body:
Would need some sort of manpage parser, to fix this.

softwrap is the default because in practice this doesn't matter too much, and softwrap is more flexible and works better for the common case. Meanwhile, hardwrap is available for those that care about this.

> When using hard wrap Neovim does format the table into multiple rows. So Neovim seem to have this capability somewhere and it should be possible that tables in soft wrap mode also get multi line cells.

Wrong. Neovim does not do any formatting itself. It simply tells `man` to format the pages for one of the following widths, before displaying that output as-is (minus highlighting):

`999` if `g:man_hardwrap = 0`. This breaks the table formatting with soft-wrap. Neovim has no way to fix this other than to re-parse the tables itself somehow. 

`MANWIDTH` if `MANWIDTH` is already set in vim's environment.

`window_width - wrapmargin` otherwise.

Personally, I set `vim.env.MANWIDTH=80` and use an autocmd which always resizes `:Man` windows to 80 columns on open (so using hardwrap), which works pretty well for reading and doesn't have issues with wrapping, though this also means I basically never resize the buffer.

```lua
local augroup = vim.api.nvim_create_augroup
local autocmd = vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd

vim.env.MANWIDTH = 80

autocmd('BufWinEnter', {
    group = augroup('vsplit-docs', { clear = true }),
    callback = function()
        if vim.v.vim_did_enter == 0 then return end
        if vim.o.buftype == 'help' or vim.o.filetype == 'man' then
            vim.lo.colorcolumn = ''
            vim.lo.cursorlineopt = 'line'
            vim.cmd('wincmd H | wincmd 80 |')
        end
    end,
    desc = 'Open documentation windows to the left in 80-column vertical split'
})
```

It also formats the tables quite well this way, using the full width of the window: 
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3691d862-ecc3-4209-8e32-a1cb596752c0)

I believe the maximum table width is either up to the manpage author, or the formatter (i.e. `groff`/`troff`/etc. ?). The widest table in `systemd.unit` seems to cap at 207 columns.

Maybe one could experiment with something like `WinResized` autocmds and dynamically toggling the `wrap` option based on some threshold, + setting `MANWIDTH` to some fixed threshold. Or even just adding a mapping to `:setlocal wrap!` to toggle wrap on and off, in combination with soft-wrapping.

Ultimately, manpages are designed to be a fixed width medium, there isn't really a good way to make them dynamic the way say responsive web pages can be (unless we converted manpages to html and then implemented some sort of responsive HTML-rendering in Neovim... :sweat_smile:)
